snippet: The share of young adults without health insurance fell by one-sixth in 2011 from the previous year, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention study finds share of young adults without health insurance fell by one-sixth in 2011 from the previous year, largest annual decline for any age group since the CDC began collecting data in 1997; study attributes the increased coverage to a provision in the Affordable Care Act that allows children to stay on their parents' insurance policies until their 26th birthday.
lead_paragraph: The share of young adults without health insurance fell by one-sixth in 2011 from the previous year, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline.seo: More Young Adults Have Health Insurance, Study Says
headline.main: More Young Adults Have Insurance After Health Care Law, Study Says
headline.print_headline: More Young Adults Have Insurance After Health Care Law, Study Says
